newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks plummet in early trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks plummet in early trade.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks plunged in early Tuesday morning trade as investors and traders left the market following Wall Street's Easter holiday slide, brokers said.
"This is a reaction to the Dow's 300-point fall," said Peter Lai, associate director of OCBC Securities. "Hong Kong always reacts more vigorously."
The Hang Seng was trading 494 points lower at 12,040 after bouncing off 12,029.39, the morning's low and the lowest point the market has traded this year.
Turnover was a healthy HK$1.42 billion after 30 minutes of trade.
The Dow industrials posted their sixth largest point drop in history on Monday, sliding 157.11 points or 2.33 percent to 6,583.48, after falling 140 points on Thursday.
The April Hang Seng Futures contract hit a low of 11,850 at the open, then bounced back slightly to trade 508 points lower at 11,955 on trade of 7,000 contracts.
The May contract was 485 points at 11,975 but on very little turnover.
"In the short term, we are likely to remain at the 12,000 for a while," said Lai.
Properties led the market down, with the sector index down 5.38 percent. Finance followed with a drop of 3.81 percent.
Cheung Kong Holdings slipped HK$4.00 to HK$64.25, off 5.9 percent and Henderson Land shed HK$3.50 to HK$60.50, off 5.45 percent.
Index heavyweight HSBC Holdings plummeted HK$7.50 or 4.2 percent at HK$172.50 and Hang Seng Bank slid HK$3.75 at HK$76.25, off 4.70 percent.
Valiantly bucking the trend at the open was COSCO Pacific which rose HK$0.05 to HK$10.25 before easing HK$0.10 to trade at HK$10.00
China Merchants Hai Hong slipped HK$0.25 to HK$5.25. The company will report final results on Tuesday.
